text:
Problem Overview

The problem begins with the Mystery Club enlarging a flier into a poster to attract new members. In this context, students create a similar figure using rubber bands. They make a stretcher by tying two rubber bands together and use it to enlarge two different figures. They compare how the general shape, line lengths, areas, perimeters, and angles are affected. This focuses students’ attention on the preservation of shape in similar figures.

Launch (Getting Started)

Connecting to Prior Knowledge

In launching this Problem, your goal is to understand what your students intuitively know about scaled drawings or similar figures. Students’ understanding will likely be based on the use of “similarity” in everyday situations. In addition, you will want to assess their measurement skills. Students will have many different strategies for finding the height of the teacher. These are some strategies you may see from your students:

Presenting the Challenge

Members of the Mystery Club want to make a poster that shows their logo. To do this, they need to enlarge the logo on the flyer they designed. Briefly discuss with students the desire to make a larger version of the original picture. Then tell them that you are going to demonstrate one method for doing so.

You will need to demonstrate how to draw a figure using a rubber band stretcher, using a marker either on the board or on chart paper taped to the wall. Test your setup before class so you know everything works. This short video shows a teacher using a rubber band stretcher to make a similar triangle.

Place the anchor point so that the enlarged drawing will not overlap the original. Choose a figure to enlarge that your students will find interesting, such as a popular cartoon character, a logo, a smiley face, or a ghost. Some teachers make a stretcher with larger rubber bands to make it easier for students to see what the teacher is doing at the board.

tiles.title: Rubber band stretcher to produce overlapping and non-overlapping figures.

text:
Explain the following to students:

  • I have a super machine called a stretcher that will help me draw a copy of this figure. My machine has two parts. Watch me carefully while I make a stretcher before your very eyes!

Tie the two rubber bands together by passing one band through the other and back through itself. Pull on the two ends, moving the knot to the center of the bands. You may need to pull on the knot so that each band forms half of the knot.

Hold your finished stretcher in the air and demonstrate its stretch. Then, use it to draw a copy of the figure as you describe the process.

  • Notice that I put one end of my stretcher on a point, called the anchor point, and hold it down securely without covering up any more of the band than necessary. I put the marker through the other end and stretch the bands until the knot is just above part of my figure. I move my marker as I trace the figure with the knot. I try to keep the knot directly over the original figure as my marker draws the new figure. I do not look at the marker as I draw. I only watch the knot. The more carefully the knot traces the original, the better my drawing will be.

Finish the drawing and ask students to describe the results. They will probably say the two figures look alike but that the new one is larger. Until they have made their own drawings, you do not need to press for more specific observations or relationships.

Distribute two rubber bands, a blank sheet of paper, and Learning Aid 1.2A: Super Sleuth to each student. Copy this Learning Aid back to back. One side of this Learning Aid is the right-handed version and the other side is the left-handed version. Help students find the correct side that they need to use. Have students tape the two sheets to their desks using masking tape as shown in the following figures and in the Student Edition. Left-handed students will have the anchor point to their right and the blank sheet of paper to their left.

tiles.title: Setup for using a rubber band stretcher

text:
Let the students make their stretchers. Some students will have a hard time tying the bands together and will need assistance. You may want to be sure everyone has made a stretcher before the class begins drawing.

Implementation Note: For this problem there are three ACE (3, 4, and 12) that involve stretching shapes and analyzing the changes. If you decide to use these ACE it might be beneficial to do the stretching in class while the rubber bands are out. Learning Aid 1.2B: Shapes to Stretch has the shapes and the anchor points on it. These shapes could also be used instead of Super Sleuth if you want a less complex shape.
